Award.AwardTitle: Provision of Research Vessel at the Shannon Point Marine Center
Award.AbstractNarration:
Western Washington University is awarded a grant to acquire a new research vessel that provides the Shannon Point Marine Center (SPMC) with the capacity to process samples from the water column at the site of collection in real time. The vessel will provide protected laboratory capacity to measure processes in the plant and animal marine microscopic community, providing a more accurate picture of the oceanic processes that regulate and drive the productivity of such systems. This new capacity will greatly expand the scope of the field research that SPMC can conduct in marine waters and the training in such processes that can be provided to both undergraduates and graduate students.

SPMC focuses on providing undergraduate with hands-on training in the most up-to-date field and laboratory investigative techniques and in actual research experience. SPMC annually provides such training to at least 18 such students, both from under-represented minority and general student populations, including community college students. The proposed vessel will provide an additional source of training to these students recruited from around the nation. SPMC also operates a Marine Public Education program that translates research activities to both K-12 and general public audiences in an effort to improve ocean science literacy. The programs targeting schools and public events include descriptions of the techniques used and information about the outcomes of research activities. Issues of water quality, harmful algal bloom ecology and fisheries productivity are common themes that occupy local discussions of land and water use. Use of the proposed vessel will enhance the ability to contribute to such discussions as a source of credible information. For more information about Shannon Point Marine Center, visit the web site at http://www.wwu.edu/spmc/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Education and science. The R/V Magister vessel has been a great benefit to Western Washington University and Shannon Point Marine Center. It has expanded out capacity for teaching environmental and marine sciences to undergraduate and graduate students by allowing faculty to take more students out on the water at one time than we were able to do before on our smaller vessels. One of the most popular courses in the Environmental Sciences Department at Western is Dr. David Shull’s Oceanography-with-laboratory course, and the ability for him to take students out to sea in Bellingham Bay on the Magister, to collect water samples and run CTDs where they can see the data profiles in real-time (see the attached photograph) has been priceless. The vessel has also been used extensively for the popular Western Marine Science Scholars Program for first and second year students, with field trips to eel grass beds and water chemistry collecting trips around northern Puget Sound.  Public outreach: Even students in the local community outside of WWU have benefited. Students in the local school districts have spent some time on the vessel (while it was at the dock) launching the remotely operated vehicles (ROVs) they designed and built during our new Extended Education WWU-Shannon Point Youth Programs Anacortes courses (see photo).

Research and collaboration. The R/V Magister increasing the capacity of WWU scientists doing funded projects that require scuba diving and benthic sampling and water column sampling.  The vessel has also been a great asset for research and monitoring programs around the Salish Sea and Puget Sound with various collaborating groups. For example, we are working with the University of Washington and Northwest Indian College to plan deployment of a long-term monitoring mooring in Bellingham Bay and the vessel is uniquely capable for handling this kind of payload, deployment (because of the A-frame and winch), and frequent visits for instrument turnarounds because of the open deck design and access. The vessel continues to be used by the Department of Ecology for monitoring work around Puget Sound and they have been impressed with its functionality.
